comment_text.dn25:1.3: The Buddha refers to the events of this sutta at DN 8:23.2, but apart from that Nigrodha (“Banyan”) appears to be unknown. A “wanderer” may or may not be Brahmanical, but in DN 8 Nigrodha is called tapabrahmacārī, which suggests he was a celibate student of a Brahmanical teacher. | The commentary describes udumbarikā (“Fig”) as devī (“Queen”), while DA 8 says she is a “brahmin lady”. She too does not seem to appear elsewhere.
comment_text.dn25:1.4: Sandhāna (“Conciliation”) was recognized as an eminent lay follower at (AN 6.120–139:1.14).
comment_text.dn25:5.10: Orodheyyāma normally means “enclose, trap” like ox in a pen (AN 6.60:3.1), but here it is glossed in the commentary as vinandheyyāma (“twist around”).
comment_text.dn25:7.9: This discourse highlights the Buddha’s method of engaging with people of other religions. He is open-hearted and interested in their views. He prefers to build on common ground, but is not afraid to criticize when it is warranted. And his aim is not to win converts, but to help people be free of suffering.
comment_text.dn25:7.16: “Higher disgust of sin” renders adhijegucche. The idea is that people are tainted with corruption, somewhat comparable to the notion of “original sin”, although due to their own actions in the past rather than ancestral legacy. In “disgust” at that sin, they practice forms of fervent mortification (tapas) to burn out the corruption.
comment_text.dn25:7.17: The phrase kathaṁ santā is unique; it echoes evaṁ sante below.
comment_text.dn25:8.4: See the passage at DN 8:14.3 and notes thereto.
comment_text.dn25:9.2: The Buddha shifts attention from the external practice to the psychological state that accompanies it.
comment_text.dn25:10.12: “In expectation” (sāpekkho): when they give up something they cannot eat, they expect to be given more suitable food.
comment_text.dn25:11.3: Asanivicakkaṁ is “forked lightning”, see Rig Veda 4.35.2 where vicakra means “divided”. | Dantakūṭa is “the crown of the tooth”.
comment_text.dn25:11.12: “Sneaks” is attānaṁ adassayamāno, literally, “not showing himself”. They like to hang about with lay folk, but hide the fact that they do so.
comment_text.dn25:12.12: As here, this item typically follows “wrong view”. At AN 10.78:1.9 it is said to be a bad quality of Jain ascetics. Thus being “attached to one’s own views” refers both to the subjective clinging as well as the objective incorrectness of the views.
comment_text.dn25:16.3: A “fourfold restraint” (cātuyāma, or cāujjāma in Jain Ardhamagadhi) is attributed to Jain founder Pārśva in Isibhāsiyāiṁ 31, where it is an abbreviated list: “from refraining from killing to refraining from possessions” (pāṇātivāta-veramaṇeṇaṁ jāvā pariggaha-veramaṇeṇaṁ); the missing items are not stealing (asteya) and truth (satya). The Jain text Uttarādhyayanasūtra 23 shows that Mahāvīra added nakedness to make five. Five are also found in Yogasūtra 2.30 and the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 7: non-harming (ahiṁsā), truth (satya), no stealing (asteya), celibacy (brahmacarya), and non-possessiveness (aparigrahā). | A different “fourfold restraint” is said to be a Jain practice at DN 2:29.2.
comment_text.dn25:16.5: This extends the basic precept. The same analysis is applied to the “ten ways of performing deeds” at AN 3.163. | The distinction between one’s own action and another’s action is noted at Isibhāsiyāiṁ 31.42, although the wording and sense are different.
comment_text.dn25:16.8: Bhāvitamāsīsati is unique. In this and similar contexts, the Pali tradition says bhāvita (“reward”, normally “developed”) is the “five sense pleasures” as they see it (bhāvitaṁ nāma tesaṁ saññāya pañca kāmaguṇā; cp. MN 56 commentary: ettha ca bhāvitanti pañcakāmaguṇā), explaining that this is a usage of the sectarians (Saddanīti ch. 4: titthiyasamaye pana bhāvitoti kāmaguṇo vuccati).
comment_text.dn25:23.4: This passage sets a powerful template for sincere engagement.
comment_text.dn25:24.2: This whole ending sequence is unique.

root_text.dn25:3.1: Addasā kho nigrodho paribbājako sandhānaṁ gahapatiṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.dn25:3.4: Ayaṁ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako āgacchati sandhāno gahapati.
root_text.dn25:3.5: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā rājagahe paṭivasanti, ayaṁ tesaṁ aññataro sandhāno gahapati.
root_text.dn25:3.6: Appasaddakāmā kho panete āyasmanto appasaddavinītā, appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino.
root_text.dn25:3.7: Appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
root_text.dn25:3.8: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn25:4.1: Atha kho sandhāno gahapati yena nigrodho paribbājako tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā nigrodhena paribbājakena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.dn25:4.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho sandhāno gahapati nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:4.3: “aññathā kho ime bhonto aññatitthiyā paribbājakā saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ anuyuttā viharanti.
root_text.dn25:4.5: Aññathā kho pana so bhagavā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppānī”ti.
root_text.dn25:5.1: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako sandhānaṁ gahapatiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:5.2: “yagghe, gahapati, jāneyyāsi, kena samaṇo gotamo saddhiṁ sallapati, kena sākacchaṁ samāpajjati, kena paññāveyyattiyaṁ samāpajjati?
root_text.dn25:5.3: Suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṁ sallāpāya.
root_text.dn25:5.5: Seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
root_text.dn25:5.10: Iṅgha, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo imaṁ parisaṁ āgaccheyya, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādeyyāma, tucchakumbhīva naṁ maññe orodheyyāmā”ti.
root_text.dn25:6.1: Assosi kho bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya sandhānassa gahapatissa nigrodhena paribbājakena saddhiṁ imaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ.
root_text.dn25:6.2: Atha kho bhagavā gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohitvā yena sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkami.
root_text.dn25:6.3: Addasā kho nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṁ sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamantaṁ.
root_text.dn25:6.5: “appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha, ayaṁ samaṇo gotamo sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamati.
root_text.dn25:6.6: Appasaddakāmo kho pana so āyasmā, appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī.
root_text.dn25:6.7: Appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyya.
root_text.dn25:6.8: Sace samaṇo gotamo imaṁ parisaṁ āgaccheyya, imaṁ taṁ pañhaṁ puccheyyāma:

root_text.dn25:6.10: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn25:7.1: Atha kho bhagavā yena nigrodho paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.dn25:7.2: Atha kho nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:7.3: “etu kho, bhante, bhagavā, svāgataṁ, bhante, bhagavato.
root_text.dn25:7.4: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
root_text.dn25:7.7: Nigrodhopi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcāsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn25:7.8: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:7.9: “kāya nuttha, nigrodha, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.dn25:7.10: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:7.11: “idha mayaṁ, bhante, addasāma bhagavantaṁ sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamantaṁ, disvāna evaṁ avocumhā:

root_text.dn25:7.13: “ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyan”’ti?
root_text.dn25:7.14: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā; atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
root_text.dn25:7.15: “Dujjānaṁ kho etaṁ, nigrodha, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena, yenāhaṁ sāvake vinemi, yena mayā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
root_text.dn25:7.16: Iṅgha tvaṁ maṁ, nigrodha, sake ācariyake adhijegucche pañhaṁ puccha:
root_text.dn25:7.17: ‘kathaṁ santā nu kho, bhante, tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā hoti, kathaṁ aparipuṇṇā’”ti?
root_text.dn25:7.18: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṁ:

root_text.dn25:8.2: “mayaṁ kho, bhante, tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharāma.
root_text.dn25:8.3: Kathaṁ santā nu kho, bhante, tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā hoti, kathaṁ aparipuṇṇā”ti?

root_text.dn25:12.10: pāpiccho hoti pāpikānaṁ icchānaṁ vasaṁ gato …
root_text.dn25:12.13: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī.
root_text.dn25:12.14: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
root_text.dn25:12.16: yadime tapojigucchā upakkilesā vā anupakkilesā vā”ti?
root_text.dn25:12.17: “Addhā kho ime, bhante, tapojigucchā upakkilesā, no anupakkilesā.
root_text.dn25:12.18: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhante, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco tapassī sabbeheva imehi upakkilesehi samannāgato assa;
root_text.dn25:13.1: “Idha, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.dn25:13.2: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.dn25:13.3: Evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.4: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.5: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.6: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na majjati na mucchati na pamādamāpajjati …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.7: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.8: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.9: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.10: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.11: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.12: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati na mucchati na pamādamāpajjati …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.13: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.14: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī bhojanesu na vodāsaṁ āpajjati:
root_text.dn25:13.16: So yañca khvassa nakkhamati, taṁ anapekkho pajahati.
root_text.dn25:13.17: Yaṁ panassa khamati, taṁ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.18: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.19: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī na tapaṁ samādiyati lābhasakkārasilokanikantihetu:
root_text.dn25:13.20: ‘sakkarissanti maṁ rājāno rājamahāmattā khattiyā brāhmaṇā gahapatikā titthiyā’ti …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.21: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:13.22: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī aññataraṁ samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā nāpasādetā hoti:
root_text.dn25:13.24: Seyyathidaṁ—mūlabījaṁ khandhabījaṁ phaḷubījaṁ aggabījaṁ bījabījameva pañcamaṁ, asanivicakkaṁ dantakūṭaṁ, samaṇappavādenā’ti …pe…
root_text.dn25:13.25: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:14.1: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī passati aññataraṁ samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā kulesu sakkariyamānaṁ garu kariyamānaṁ māniyamānaṁ pūjiyamānaṁ.
root_text.dn25:14.3: ‘imañhi nāma sambahulājīvaṁ kulesu sakkaronti garuṁ karonti mānenti pūjenti.
root_text.dn25:14.4: Maṁ pana tapassiṁ lūkhājīviṁ kulesu na sakkaronti na garuṁ karonti na mānenti na pūjentī’ti, iti so issāmacchariyaṁ kulesu nuppādetā hoti …pe…
root_text.dn25:14.5: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:14.6: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī na āpāthakanisādī hoti …pe…
root_text.dn25:14.7: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:14.8: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī na attānaṁ adassayamāno kulesu carati:
root_text.dn25:14.10: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:14.11: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī na kiñcideva paṭicchannaṁ sevati, so:
root_text.dn25:14.12: ‘khamati te idan’ti puṭṭho samāno akkhamamānaṁ āha:
root_text.dn25:14.16: Iti so sampajānamusā na bhāsitā hoti …pe…
root_text.dn25:14.17: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:15.1: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tathāgatassa vā tathāgatasāvakassa vā dhammaṁ desentassa santaṁyeva pariyāyaṁ anuññeyyaṁ anujānāti …pe…
root_text.dn25:15.2: evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:15.3: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī akkodhano hoti anupanāhī.
root_text.dn25:15.4: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī akkodhano hoti anupanāhī evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:15.5: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī amakkhī hoti apaḷāsī …pe…
root_text.dn25:15.9: na pāpiccho hoti na pāpikānaṁ icchānaṁ vasaṁ gato …
root_text.dn25:15.10: na micchādiṭṭhiko hoti na antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgato …
root_text.dn25:15.11: na sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti na ādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī.
root_text.dn25:15.12: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī na sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti na ādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī.
root_text.dn25:15.13: Evaṁ so tasmiṁ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
root_text.dn25:15.15: yadi evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
root_text.dn25:15.16: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
root_text.dn25:15.17: “Na kho, nigrodha, ettāvatā tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca;
root_text.dn25:16.1: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca?
root_text.dn25:16.2: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tapojigucchāya aggaññeva pāpetu, sāraññeva pāpetū”ti.
root_text.dn25:16.5: Idha, nigrodha, tapassī na pāṇaṁ atipāteti, na pāṇaṁ atipātayati, na pāṇamatipātayato samanuñño hoti.
root_text.dn25:16.6: Na adinnaṁ ādiyati, na adinnaṁ ādiyāpeti, na adinnaṁ ādiyato samanuñño hoti.
root_text.dn25:16.7: Na musā bhaṇati, na musā bhaṇāpeti, na musā bhaṇato samanuñño hoti.
root_text.dn25:16.8: Na bhāvitamāsīsati, na bhāvitamāsīsāpeti, na bhāvitamāsīsato samanuñño hoti.
root_text.dn25:16.9: Evaṁ kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti.
root_text.dn25:16.10: Yato kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti, aduṁ cassa hoti tapassitāya.
root_text.dn25:16.12: So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.dn25:16.13: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.dn25:16.14: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.dn25:16.15: Byāpādappadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādappadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.dn25:16.16: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.dn25:16.17: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.dn25:16.18: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.dn25:17.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.dn25:17.2: mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn25:17.5: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.

root_text.dn25:17.8: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.

root_text.dn25:18.13: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ, tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.

root_text.dn25:19.12: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.dn25:19.14: yadi evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
root_text.dn25:19.15: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
root_text.dn25:19.16: “Ettāvatā kho, nigrodha, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca.
root_text.dn25:19.17: Iti kho, nigrodha, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ avacāsi:
root_text.dn25:19.18: ‘ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyan’ti.
root_text.dn25:19.19: Iti kho taṁ, nigrodha, ṭhānaṁ uttaritarañca paṇītatarañca, yenāhaṁ sāvake vinemi, yena mayā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyan”ti.
root_text.dn25:19.20: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṁ:
root_text.dn25:19.21: “ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā, na mayaṁ ito bhiyyo uttaritaraṁ pajānāmā”ti.
root_text.dn25:20.2: “aññadatthu kho dānime aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato bhāsitaṁ sussūsanti, sotaṁ odahanti, aññācittaṁ upaṭṭhāpentī”ti.
root_text.dn25:20.4: “iti kho, bhante nigrodha, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ avacāsi:
root_text.dn25:20.5: ‘yagghe, gahapati, jāneyyāsi, kena samaṇo gotamo saddhiṁ sallapati, kena sākacchaṁ samāpajjati, kena paññāveyyattiyaṁ samāpajjati,
root_text.dn25:20.6: suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṁ sallāpāya, so antamantāneva sevati;
root_text.dn25:20.7: seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
root_text.dn25:20.8: Evameva suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṁ sallāpāya; so antamantāneva sevati;
root_text.dn25:20.9: iṅgha, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo imaṁ parisaṁ āgaccheyya, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādeyyāma, tucchakumbhīva naṁ maññe orodheyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn25:20.10: Ayaṁ kho so, bhante, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho idhānuppatto, aparisāvacaraṁ pana naṁ karotha, gokāṇaṁ pariyantacāriniṁ karotha, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādetha, tucchakumbhīva naṁ orodhethā”ti.
root_text.dn25:20.11: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
root_text.dn25:21.1: Atha kho bhagavā nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ maṅkubhūtaṁ pattakkhandhaṁ adhomukhaṁ pajjhāyantaṁ appaṭibhānaṁ viditvā nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:21.2: “saccaṁ kira, nigrodha, bhāsitā te esā vācā”ti?
root_text.dn25:21.3: “Saccaṁ, bhante, bhāsitā me esā vācā, yathābālena yathāmūḷhena yathāakusalenā”ti.
root_text.dn25:21.5: Kinti te sutaṁ paribbājakānaṁ vuḍḍhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.dn25:21.6: ‘ye te ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, evaṁ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ anuyuttā viharanti.
root_text.dn25:21.9: Udāhu, evaṁ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpāhaṁ etarahī’”ti.
root_text.dn25:21.10: “Sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante. Paribbājakānaṁ vuḍḍhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.dn25:21.11: ‘ye te ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, na evaṁ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ anuyuttā viharanti.
root_text.dn25:21.14: Evaṁ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpi bhagavā etarahī’”ti.
root_text.dn25:21.15: “Tassa te, nigrodha, viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi:
root_text.dn25:21.16: ‘buddho so bhagavā bodhāya dhammaṁ deseti, danto so bhagavā damathāya dhammaṁ deseti, santo so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṁ deseti, tiṇṇo so bhagavā taraṇāya dhammaṁ deseti, parinibbuto so bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammaṁ desetī’”ti?
root_text.dn25:22.1: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn25:22.2: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yvāhaṁ evaṁ bhagavantaṁ avacāsiṁ.
root_text.dn25:22.3: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
root_text.dn25:22.4: “Taggha tvaṁ, nigrodha, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yo maṁ tvaṁ evaṁ avacāsi.
root_text.dn25:22.5: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, nigrodha, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
root_text.dn25:22.6: Vuddhi hesā, nigrodha, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.dn25:22.7: Ahaṁ kho pana, nigrodha, evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.dn25:22.8: ‘Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn25:22.9: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattavassāni.
root_text.dn25:22.11: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn25:22.12: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati cha vassāni.
root_text.dn25:22.19: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn25:22.20: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati satta māsāni.
root_text.dn25:22.30: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn25:22.31: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattāhaṁ’.
root_text.dn25:23.1: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
root_text.dn25:23.3: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.4: Yo eva vo ācariyo, so eva vo ācariyo hotu.
root_text.dn25:23.5: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
root_text.dn25:23.7: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.8: Yo eva vo uddeso so eva vo uddeso hotu.
root_text.dn25:23.9: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
root_text.dn25:23.11: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.12: Yo eva vo ājīvo, so eva vo ājīvo hotu.
root_text.dn25:23.13: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
root_text.dn25:23.14: ‘ye no dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
root_text.dn25:23.15: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.16: Akusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu akusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.17: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
root_text.dn25:23.18: ‘ye no dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tehi vivecetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
root_text.dn25:23.19: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.20: Kusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu kusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṁ.
root_text.dn25:23.21: Iti khvāhaṁ, nigrodha, neva antevāsikamyatā evaṁ vadāmi, napi uddesā cāvetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ājīvā cāvetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tehi vivecetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi.
root_text.dn25:23.22: Santi ca kho, nigrodha, akusalā dhammā appahīnā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, yesāhaṁ pahānāya dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn25:23.23: Yathāpaṭipannānaṁ vo saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodānīyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṁ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
root_text.dn25:24.1: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhībhūtā maṅkubhūtā pattakkhandhā adhomukhā pajjhāyantā appaṭibhānā nisīdiṁsu yathā taṁ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacittā.
root_text.dn25:24.4: Yatra hi nāma ekassapi na evaṁ bhavissati:
root_text.dn25:24.5: ‘handa mayaṁ aññāṇatthampi samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ carāma, kiṁ karissati sattāho’”ti?
root_text.dn25:24.6: Atha kho bhagavā udumbarikāya paribbājakārāme sīhanādaṁ naditvā vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā gijjhakūṭe pabbate paccupaṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn25:24.7: Sandhāno pana gahapati tāvadeva rājagahaṁ pāvisīti.

translation_text.dn25:0.2: The Lion’s Roar at the Monastery of Lady Udumbarikā
translation_text.dn25:1.0: 1. The Story of the Wanderer Nigrodha
translation_text.dn25:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.dn25:1.3: Now at that time the wanderer Nigrodha was residing in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, together with a large assembly of three thousand wanderers.
translation_text.dn25:1.4: Then the householder Sandhāna left Rājagaha in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
translation_text.dn25:1.6: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
translation_text.dn25:1.8: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,
translation_text.dn25:1.10: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Nigrodha at the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers?”
translation_text.dn25:1.11: So he went to the monastery of the wanderers.
translation_text.dn25:2.1: Now at that time, Nigrodha was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
translation_text.dn25:2.2: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
translation_text.dn25:3.1: Nigrodha saw Sandhāna coming off in the distance,
translation_text.dn25:3.3: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
translation_text.dn25:3.4: The householder Sandhāna, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.
translation_text.dn25:3.5: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Rājagaha.
translation_text.dn25:3.6: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
translation_text.dn25:3.7: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
translation_text.dn25:4.1: Then Sandhāna went up to the wanderer Nigrodha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn25:4.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Nigrodha,
translation_text.dn25:4.3: “The way the wanderers make an uproar as they sit together and talk about all kinds of low topics is one thing.
translation_text.dn25:4.5: It’s quite different to the way the Buddha frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.”
translation_text.dn25:5.1: When Sandhāna said this, Nigrodha said to him,
translation_text.dn25:5.2: “Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?
translation_text.dn25:5.3: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion.
translation_text.dn25:5.4: He just lurks on the periphery.
translation_text.dn25:5.5: He’s just like a one-eyed cow, circling around and lurking on the periphery.
translation_text.dn25:5.10: Go on, householder! Were the ascetic Gotama to come to this assembly, I’d sink him with just one question! I’d tie him up like a hollow pot!”
translation_text.dn25:6.1: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard this discussion between the householder Sandhāna and the wanderer Nigrodha.
translation_text.dn25:6.2: Then the Buddha descended from Vulture’s Peak Mountain and went to the peacocks’ feeding ground on the bank of the Sumāgadhā, where he walked mindfully in the open air.
translation_text.dn25:6.5: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound. The ascetic Gotama is walking mindfully on the bank of the Sumāgadhā.
translation_text.dn25:6.6: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
translation_text.dn25:6.7: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.
translation_text.dn25:6.8: If he comes, I’ll ask him this question:
translation_text.dn25:6.9: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’”
translation_text.dn25:7.1: Then the Buddha went up to the wanderer Nigrodha,
translation_text.dn25:7.3: “Let the Blessed One come, sir! Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
translation_text.dn25:7.4: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.dn25:7.5: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.dn25:7.6: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.dn25:7.7: while Nigrodha took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.dn25:7.9: “Nigrodha, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.dn25:7.11: “Well, sir, I saw you walking mindfully and said:
translation_text.dn25:7.12: ‘If the ascetic Gotama comes, I’ll ask him this question:
translation_text.dn25:7.13: “Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?”’
translation_text.dn25:7.14: This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
translation_text.dn25:7.15: “It’s hard for you to understand this, Nigrodha, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.
translation_text.dn25:7.16: Please ask me a question about the higher disgust of sin in your own tradition:
translation_text.dn25:7.17: ‘How are the conditions for the fervent mortification in disgust of sin completed, and how are they incomplete?’”
translation_text.dn25:7.18: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,
translation_text.dn25:7.19: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The ascetic Gotama has such power and might! For he sets aside his own doctrine and invites discussion on the doctrine of others!”
translation_text.dn25:8.1: Then Nigrodha, having quieted those wanderers, said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn25:8.2: “Sir, we teach fervent mortification in disgust of sin, regarding it as essential and sticking to it.
translation_text.dn25:8.3: How are the conditions for the fervent mortification in disgust of sin completed, and how are they incomplete?”
translation_text.dn25:8.4: “Nigrodha, it’s when a mortifier goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.dn25:8.5: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breast-feeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.dn25:8.6: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.dn25:8.7: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.dn25:8.8: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.dn25:8.9: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.dn25:8.10: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.dn25:8.11: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
translation_text.dn25:8.12: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.dn25:8.13: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
translation_text.dn25:8.14: They make their bed on a plank, or the bare ground.
translation_text.dn25:8.15: They lie only on one side.
translation_text.dn25:8.17: They stay in the open air.
translation_text.dn25:8.18: They sleep wherever they lay their mat.
translation_text.dn25:8.19: They eat unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods.
translation_text.dn25:8.20: They don’t drink, committed to the practice of not drinking liquids.
translation_text.dn25:8.21: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
translation_text.dn25:8.23: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin complete, or incomplete?”
translation_text.dn25:8.24: “Clearly, sir, if that is so the fervent mortification in disgust of sin is complete, not incomplete.”
translation_text.dn25:8.25: “But even such a completed mortification has many defects, I say.”
translation_text.dn25:9.1: “But how does the Buddha say that even such a completed mortification has many defects?”
translation_text.dn25:9.2: “Firstly, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.dn25:9.4: This is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:9.5: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.dn25:9.7: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:9.8: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They become indulgent and infatuated and fall into negligence on account of that.
translation_text.dn25:9.10: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:10.1: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.dn25:10.3: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:10.4: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.dn25:10.6: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:10.7: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They become indulgent and infatuated and fall into negligence on account of that.
translation_text.dn25:10.9: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:10.10: Furthermore, a mortifier becomes fussy about food, saying,
translation_text.dn25:10.11: ‘This is acceptable to me, this is not acceptable to me.’
translation_text.dn25:10.12: What is not acceptable they give up in expectation.
translation_text.dn25:10.13: But what is acceptable they eat tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
translation_text.dn25:10.14: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:10.15: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity, thinking,
translation_text.dn25:10.16: ‘Kings, royal ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and sectarians will honor me!’
translation_text.dn25:10.17: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:11.1: Furthermore, a mortifier rebukes a certain ascetic or brahmin,
translation_text.dn25:11.2: ‘What is it with this one living in abundance, devouring everything—
translation_text.dn25:11.3: plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. According to this ascetic’s doctrine, the crown of the tooth is forked lightning!’
translation_text.dn25:11.4: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:11.5: Furthermore, a mortifier sees a certain ascetic or brahmin being honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.
translation_text.dn25:11.7: ‘This one, who lives in abundance, is honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.
translation_text.dn25:11.8: But I, a fervent mortifier who lives rough, am not honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.’ Thus they give rise to jealousy and stinginess regarding families.
translation_text.dn25:11.9: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:11.10: Furthermore, a mortifier sits meditation only when people can see them.
translation_text.dn25:11.11: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:11.12: Furthermore, a mortifier sneaks about among families, thinking,
translation_text.dn25:11.13: ‘This is part of my mortification; this is part of my mortification.’
translation_text.dn25:11.14: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:11.15: Furthermore, a mortifier sometimes behaves in an underhand manner.
translation_text.dn25:11.16: When asked whether something is acceptable to them, they say it is, even though it isn’t.
translation_text.dn25:11.17: Or they say it isn’t, even though it is.
translation_text.dn25:11.18: Thus they tell a deliberate lie.
translation_text.dn25:11.19: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:12.1: Furthermore, a mortifier disagrees with the way that the Realized One or their disciple teaches Dhamma, even when they make a valid point.
translation_text.dn25:12.2: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:12.3: Furthermore, a mortifier is irritable and acrimonious …
translation_text.dn25:12.10: they have corrupt wishes, falling under the sway of corrupt wishes …
translation_text.dn25:12.11: they have wrong view, being attached to an extremist view …
translation_text.dn25:12.12: they’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
translation_text.dn25:12.14: This too is a defect in that mortifier.
translation_text.dn25:12.16: Are such mortifications defective or not?”
translation_text.dn25:12.18: It’s possible that a mortifier might have all of these defects,
translation_text.dn25:12.19: let alone one or other of them.”
translation_text.dn25:13.1: “Firstly, Nigrodha, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. But they’re not happy with that, as they still haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.dn25:13.3: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:13.4: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They don’t glorify themselves or put others down on account of that.
translation_text.dn25:13.5: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:13.8: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They’re not happy with that, as they still haven’t got all they wished for …
translation_text.dn25:13.10: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of possessions, honor, and popularity …
translation_text.dn25:13.12: They don’t become indulgent because of it …
translation_text.dn25:13.13: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:13.14: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t become fussy about food, saying,
translation_text.dn25:13.15: ‘This is acceptable to me, this is not acceptable to me.’
translation_text.dn25:13.16: What is not acceptable they give up without concern.
translation_text.dn25:13.17: But what is acceptable they eat without being tied, infatuated, attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.
translation_text.dn25:13.18: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:13.19: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t undertake a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity …
translation_text.dn25:13.20: ‘Kings, royal ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and sectarians will honor me!’
translation_text.dn25:13.21: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:13.22: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t rebuke a certain ascetic or brahmin,
translation_text.dn25:13.23: ‘What is it with this one living in abundance, devouring everything—
translation_text.dn25:13.24: plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. According to this ascetic’s doctrine, the crown of the tooth is like forked lightning!’
translation_text.dn25:13.25: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:14.1: Furthermore, a mortifier sees a certain ascetic or brahmin being honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.
translation_text.dn25:14.3: ‘This one, who lives in abundance, is honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.
translation_text.dn25:14.4: But I, a fervent mortifier who lives rough, am not honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.’ Thus they don’t give rise to jealousy and stinginess regarding families.
translation_text.dn25:14.5: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:14.6: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t sit meditation only when people can see them.
translation_text.dn25:14.7: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:14.8: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t sneak about among families, thinking,
translation_text.dn25:14.9: ‘This is part of my mortification; this is part of my mortification.’
translation_text.dn25:14.10: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:14.11: Furthermore, a mortifier never behaves in an underhand manner.
translation_text.dn25:14.12: When asked whether something is acceptable to them, they say it isn’t when it isn’t.
translation_text.dn25:14.14: Or they say it is when it is.
translation_text.dn25:14.16: Thus they don’t tell a deliberate lie.
translation_text.dn25:14.17: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:15.1: Furthermore, a mortifier agrees with the way that the Realized One or their disciple teaches Dhamma when they make a valid point.
translation_text.dn25:15.2: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:15.3: Furthermore, a mortifier is not irritable and acrimonious …
translation_text.dn25:15.11: they’re not attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
translation_text.dn25:15.13: So they’re pure on that point.
translation_text.dn25:15.15: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”
translation_text.dn25:15.16: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”
translation_text.dn25:15.17: “No, Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith.
translation_text.dn25:15.18: Rather, it has only reached the shoots.”
translation_text.dn25:16.1: “But at what point, sir, does the fervent mortification in disgust of sin reach the peak and the pith?
translation_text.dn25:16.2: Please help me reach the peak and the pith!”
translation_text.dn25:16.3: “Nigrodha, take a mortifier who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
translation_text.dn25:16.4: And how is a mortifier restrained in the fourfold constraint?
translation_text.dn25:16.5: It’s when a mortifier doesn’t kill living creatures, doesn’t get others to kill, and doesn’t approve of killing.
translation_text.dn25:16.6: They don’t steal, get others to steal, or approve of stealing.
translation_text.dn25:16.7: They don’t lie, get others to lie, or approve of lying.
translation_text.dn25:16.8: They don’t expect rewards from their practice, they don’t lead others to expect rewards, and they don’t approve of expecting rewards.
translation_text.dn25:16.9: That’s how a mortifier is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
translation_text.dn25:16.10: When a mortifier is restrained in the fourfold constraint, that is their mortification.
translation_text.dn25:16.11: They step forward, not falling back.
translation_text.dn25:16.12: They frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.dn25:16.13: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.dn25:16.14: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.dn25:16.15: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.dn25:16.16: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.dn25:16.17: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.dn25:16.18: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.dn25:17.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.dn25:17.2: Then they meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn25:17.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.dn25:17.4: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
translation_text.dn25:17.5: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn25:17.7: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”
translation_text.dn25:17.8: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”
translation_text.dn25:17.9: “No, Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith.
translation_text.dn25:17.10: Rather, it has only reached the bark.”

translation_text.dn25:18.13: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn25:18.15: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”
translation_text.dn25:18.16: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

translation_text.dn25:19.8: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.dn25:19.9: Then they meditate spreading a heart full of love …
translation_text.dn25:19.11: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn25:19.12: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.dn25:19.14: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”
translation_text.dn25:19.15: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”
translation_text.dn25:19.16: “Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has reached the peak and the pith.
translation_text.dn25:19.17: Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:
translation_text.dn25:19.18: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’
translation_text.dn25:19.19: Well, there is something better and finer than this. That’s what I use to guide my disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.”
translation_text.dn25:19.20: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,
translation_text.dn25:19.21: “In that case, we’re lost, and so is our tradition! We don’t know anything better or finer than that!”
translation_text.dn25:20.2: “Obviously, now these wanderers want to listen to what the Buddha says. They’re actively listening and trying to understand!”
translation_text.dn25:20.3: So he said to the wanderer Nigrodha,
translation_text.dn25:20.4: “Honorable Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:
translation_text.dn25:20.5: ‘Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?
translation_text.dn25:20.6: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion. He just lurks on the periphery.
translation_text.dn25:20.7: He’s just like a one-eyed cow, circling around and lurking on the periphery.
translation_text.dn25:20.9: Please, householder, let the ascetic Gotama come to this assembly. I’ll sink him with just one question! I’ll roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot!’
translation_text.dn25:20.10: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a one-eyed cow? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”
translation_text.dn25:20.11: When he said this, Nigrodha sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
translation_text.dn25:21.1: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.dn25:21.2: “Is it really true, Nigrodha—are those your words?”
translation_text.dn25:21.3: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”
translation_text.dn25:21.5: Have you heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said that
translation_text.dn25:21.6: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they made an uproar, a colossal racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of low topics,
translation_text.dn25:21.8: like you do in your tradition these days?
translation_text.dn25:21.9: Or did they say that the Buddhas frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat, like I do these days?”
translation_text.dn25:21.10: “I have heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, said that
translation_text.dn25:21.11: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they didn’t make an uproar,
translation_text.dn25:21.13: like I do in my tradition these days.
translation_text.dn25:21.14: They said that the Buddhas of the past frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness, like the Buddha does these days.”
translation_text.dn25:21.15: “Nigrodha, you are a sensible and mature man. Did it not occur to you:
translation_text.dn25:21.16: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and quenched. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, taming, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment’?”
translation_text.dn25:22.0: 5. The Culmination of the Spiritual Path
translation_text.dn25:22.2: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to speak in that way.
translation_text.dn25:22.3: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.dn25:22.4: “Indeed, Nigrodha, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to speak in that way.
translation_text.dn25:22.5: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
translation_text.dn25:22.6: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.
translation_text.dn25:22.7: Nigrodha, this is what I say:
translation_text.dn25:22.8: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
translation_text.dn25:22.9: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven years. They will live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

translation_text.dn25:22.12: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in six years …
translation_text.dn25:22.30: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
translation_text.dn25:22.31: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven days.
translation_text.dn25:23.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants pupils.’
translation_text.dn25:23.3: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn25:23.4: Let your tutor remain your tutor.
translation_text.dn25:23.6: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our recitation.’
translation_text.dn25:23.7: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn25:23.8: Let your recitation remain as it is.
translation_text.dn25:23.10: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our livelihood.’
translation_text.dn25:23.11: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn25:23.12: Let your livelihood remain as it is.
translation_text.dn25:23.14: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to start doing things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in our tradition.’
translation_text.dn25:23.15: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn25:23.16: Let those things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in your tradition remain as they are.
translation_text.dn25:23.18: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to stop doing things that are skillful and considered skillful in our tradition.’
translation_text.dn25:23.19: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn25:23.20: Let those things that are skillful and considered skillful in your tradition remain as they are.
translation_text.dn25:23.21: I do not speak for any of these reasons.
translation_text.dn25:23.22: Nigrodha, there are things that are unskillful, corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. I teach Dhamma so that those things may be given up.
translation_text.dn25:23.23: When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.”
translation_text.dn25:24.1: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, as if their minds were possessed by Māra.
translation_text.dn25:24.2: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn25:24.3: “All these silly people have been touched by the Wicked One!
translation_text.dn25:24.4: For not even a single one thinks,
translation_text.dn25:24.5: ‘Come, let us lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama for the sake of enlightenment—for what do seven days matter?’”
translation_text.dn25:24.6: Then the Buddha, having roared his lion’s roar in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, rose into the air and landed on Vulture’s Peak.
translation_text.dn25:24.7: Meanwhile, the householder Sandhāna went right back to Rājagaha.
